<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_EndTest:
```c
void UtAssert_EndTest(void)
{
    uint32                 Ct;
    bool                   SegmentValid;
    UtAssert_TestCounter_t Local_SegmentCounters;
    char                   Local_SegmentName[sizeof(CurrentSegment)];

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    SegmentValid = (UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases > 0);
    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        ++UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_SegmentCounters.TestSegmentCount = UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_TotalCounters.TotalTestCases += UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;
        for (Ct = 0; Ct < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX; ++Ct)
        {
            UT_TotalCounters.CaseCount[Ct] += UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[Ct];
        }
        memcpy(&Local_SegmentCounters, &UT_SegmentCounters, sizeof(Local_SegmentCounters));

        /*
         * note, strcpy is OK because both are fixed size buffers of the same size,
         * and the null termination on CurrentSegment was locally enforced already
         */
        strcpy(Local_SegmentName, CurrentSegment);
    }

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(Local_SegmentName, &Local_SegmentCounters);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, "No test cases\n");
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
char                   Local_SegmentName[sizeof(CurrentSegment)];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If CurrentSegment is not an array but a pointer (e.g. declared as "char *CurrentSegment"), sizeof(CurrentSegment) yields the pointer size (4 or 8), so Local_SegmentName is too small. Then strcpy(Local_SegmentName, CurrentSegment) can write beyond Local_SegmentName (and may read beyond the source if it is not null-terminated), causing an out-of-bounds access and thus violating MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
